I love this lactic acid peel! The included instruction file is very informative. I do think they should have included a written printout with each order though, especially since that is the only way you would know how to use this product if you aren't familiar with using facial peels. There are tips and tricks that help you get the most out of using this product, along with other products sold by the company. For those that don't wish to download the file, or have receive this as a gift, here is a condensed version of the directions.

Always perform a patch test in an inconspicuous spot (the forearm is a good place). Leave the test solution on for at least 1 minute before washing it off with water. Wait 24 hours for any sign of irritation. Never use your peel around your eyes or on your lips.  Always use reasonable judgment.  If excessive irritation or stinging occurs, rinse off immediately and discontinue. Never use any products with fragrances or exfoliation properties for 48 hours after your procedure - these include retinol or retin-A products, benzoyl peroxide or other acne drying solutions and any and all `grainy' face scrubs.

1. Cleanse the skin thoroughly and rinse well.

2. With a cotton pad, wipe rubbing alcohol over your entire face and allow to air dry. (alcohol wipes work really well here).  A good toner or witch hazel can also work in the place of rubbing alcohol.

3. Wet either gauze, a cotton pad or a fan brush with1-2 mls and wipe over your face. Try to apply as thin and even a layer as possible.  Take care around the delicate skin  around your nose and leave at least a 2mm (1 inch) margin between the edge of your eye area and the peel. DO NOT rub into the skin.

4. Allow the peel to remain on your skin for 2-5 minutes, depending on your tolerance.  For your first 2 or 3 peels, never leave the solution on for more than 2 minutes. Watch your skin for signs of irritation.

5. Prepare a neutralizing solution of 1 Tablespoon of Baking Soda in a bowl of tepid water. This solution will immediately deactivate the chemical reaction.

6. Rinse your face until all water has been used.  You cannot rinse your face too much.  You should not feel any stinging on your face at this point.

After using the peel follow up with a good moisturizer. I like to use face serums with hyaluronic acid after using peels, it feels soothing to my skin. This facial peel really does work well, it has helped me get rid of the top dry and dull layers of skin, and what has shown up looks and feels softer and nicer. I really have noticed an overall improvement to the appearance of my skin, so I will continue using this every couple of weeks.

I pride myself on being a Essential Oil enthusiast. I'm into mixing my own 100% Pure Essential Oil recipes. From disinfectant spray, to wasp spray, and bedroom spray-I like natural and fresh scents. After browsing this page, the glass bottles looked similar to other glass bottles I've purchased. Normally I base my purchases off reviews however, few reviews were posted at the time (some for the product and some against it). Taking a chance, I ordered the set and they arrived quickly. The package contained two Cobalt Blue Glass bottles with plastic spray triggers. The issue I have is with the spray nozzles. If your using 100% Pure Essential Oils in your mixtures after a few sprays, the nozzles will clog or eventually quit working. To avoid this problem most sellers will include a cap (for free). By including a cap you are able to shake and combine your oils, witch hazel, vodka, etc. When you shake up your bottles using the plastic sprayers the oils will slowly eat away at the inner rim. I contacted the seller and they kindly explained no one has brought this problem to their attention, the company- will look into it. I uploaded some pictures, in one of the pictures I show the difference between a powerful spray nozzle versus the flimsy nozzle. Also included is a picture of how I bottle and label my mixtures. I appreciate you for taking time out to read my review. I hope it was informative.

Update October 11, 2016- I started the Atkins diet. For anyone who has been on Atkins, you know this means bad breath and foul body odor as the body excretes ketones. Ick. Double ick. I have job interviews to attend and I can't show up smelling like a cesspit. These are helping keep my body odor free. My only negative thought about them is the coating flakes off if they are stored long term or banged around in a purse. It doesn't lessen their effect, but it does make them a bit messy.

These work on me by removing the smell of onions or alcohol seeping out my pores and my breath. I take a dose before stinky food or drink and then again around two hours later. I generally take three doses the first day then another dose the next morning.

There are some meals that are full of onions and garlic. I don't want to smell like sour onions or garlic for three days. These help resolve the issue. Most of the time these pills can at least lessen the smell exuding from my pores and stop the bad breath. For me, and for the few people I have had try them, they work.

They saved at least one relationship I had where the man had a major problem with eating onions or garlic. He could come home after eating those for lunch and I would smell it on his skin. Not on his breath, literally on his skin. The Mint Asure helped keep that from happening and within around an hour of taking the pills, the smell exuding from him would lessen.  I have been a fan of these since they were called "Breath Assure".

The new mint coating does make them harder to take without water, but taking them with water seems to help get them into the system faster so I don't mind it. I don't find that the mint coating does much to freshen breath on it's own.

Don't know why they work, but I am glad they do!

I've bought a few sets of similar brushes on Amazon, and they're all basically the same thing.  There must be a single manufacturer or wholesale supplier, and then each seller rebrands them and distributes them as their own.  With that understanding though, these are still excellent.  The synthetic bristles do NOT drink up your foundation, so you don't lose liquid on application.  It's expensive to keep wasting foundation that gets trapped in the brush and washed down the drain after every use.  Also, the bristles are cut evenly, so all the brush shapes look correct.  I've purchased at least one set where the bristles were cut so crookedly that it looked like someone assembled the brush while blindfolded.

Three things:

1.  I'm sure people are  going to complain about how the brush roll smells strongly synthetic when you open it up.  It does.  But it goes away almost immediately.  It's the same kind of smell that you find on a lot of new plastic items.  Remember the way it smells when you unpack a new TV or DVR?  It's like that.  After a few minutes, you wouldn't notice it unless you stuck your face in it.  After a few hours, it's essentially gone.

2.  There's no explanation as to what each brush is for.  That doesn't bother me a bit, since I can always find a good use for a clean brush.

3.  The great thing about this set is that they DO NOT have logos on the handles, as shown in the product images.  The set I received has matte black handles, with no writing at all---which just how I prefer them to be.  Logos are distracting.

FYI, there's no storage space for any other makeup items.  I think it would have been clever to add a small zip pocket on the back of the brush roll, but I know that would have been potentially bulky and inconvenient.

Bottom line:  this was a great purchase.  I'm happy with this set, and I actually prefer to use these over my far more expensive Sephora brushes.  If I had known about these brushes before paying so much money for the Sephora brand, I would have bought these first.  They're soft, dense, they dry quickly after washing, and the bristles don't suck up all your foundation.  That's as good as it gets.

The 7825XL, 7845XL, 7865XL and 7885XL models are all basically the same razor, differing only in the way they display battery/charging  status (anywhere from 1 LED to a complete tiny LCD display).  The shaving peformance is fine for me -- not as close as a wet shave but that's a good thing for me personally because the closeness of wet shaves makes my face break out.  Every 3-7 years I buy a new Norelco and they get incrementally better each time.

I'm writing to warn about one feature.  Every shaver I'd had up to this one had a physical slider switch to turn it on and off.  This models has a push button.  This means you can't tell BY TOUCH whether it's on or off.  This is critical for me because I usually shave in the car (sitting in traffic) with the stereo blaring and I can't hear the shaver (especially since the newer models are pretty quiet).  I turn it on and off a lot as traffic conditions change.

Further, when the battery is low, my previous shavers would just run slower and slower until they came to a gradual stop.  This one slows slightly (imperceptably to me, really) and then just "falls off the cliff" and stops cold.  So you don't get any warning really that it's about to run out -- if I knew it was running down, then I'd shave a lot faster!

And this is where the tactile power switch feedback is important:  if the battery's totally drained, but I'm not done yet, I'll leave it off for a minute and then turn it on for 5-10 seconds of shaving before it dies again.  With the push-button power control this is really confusing because you're never really sure what's on and off.  It turns out the the power button is like a pulse that gets sent to an internal microcontroller (I'm guessing), so after it's been off for a while the power "position" doesn't matter, it's really off.  You just push to reboot the thing.

So, my 7825XL was robbed out of my car last night and I'm buying another one of these, so I guess that's an endorsement.  But I'm bumping up to the next higher model with better battery status indication ...

Exfolikate is a great product--sort of a cross between an exfoliating scrub and a mild superficial peel--and it gives instant results, which is more than can be said for a lot of cosmetic products. I've used Exfolikate for several years, and it *does* live up to the hype and cult-following; you get results after even a single use. Some people don't like Exfolikate because they think it's too aggressive; I once heard someone say it should be used for scrubbing bathrooms!! I think it really depends on how your skin is....and only you know that best. For me, it works very well--my oily skin doesn't slough off easily, causing skin particles, oil, and hard water in San Francisco to combine into invisible pore-clogging scum. Exfolikate helps---it removes dead skin to smooth my face and de-gunks my pores so they're (temporarily) less noticeable. I use it 1-2 times per week, and leave it on for about 3-4 minutes prior to showering. From personal experience, let me warn you: DO NOT try leaving it on longer because you think you'll get even better results. I once left it on for 25 minutes, and really regretted it; it took off too much surface, leaving me with raw skin which kind of dried out/peeled off after a couple of days. Lesson learned the hard way. If you use it right, starting conservatively until you know how your skin can handle things, it's a great option. It's on my "top favorites" skincare list, along with Dr. Dennis Gross Skincare Alpha Beta Daily Face Peel, Original Strength, 30 Packettes and Clinique Acne Solutions Oil-Control Cleansing Mask I'm a repeat customer for Exfolikate, and definitely recommend it to anyone who is tired of cosmetic products that don't deliver on their promises. But the heads function efficiently for a very long time before you feel that they should be replaced---maybe the replacement icon is a bit of a marketing ploy--the set of replacement heads costs about $30. Like many Norelcos of that kind, this one has a trimmer in the back--good for trimming the mustache and edge hairs. All in all this is a fun and efficient electric razor that is the best that I have ever had. The only notable wear and tear on mine is the rubber wearing and tearing off in the area of the swith--but is normal depreciation from long-term use.

I am a dentist who recommends Crest-brand White Strips to my patients becasue they do work to whiten teeth. However, they have to be used correctly and I recommend that you follow the directions exactly as specified inside the box.

1. First brush your teeth with a wet toothbrush to remove the layer of plaque (toothpaste is unnecessary). Rinse your teeth well with water.  Tooth enamel has pores, and the pores need to be open for the chemical to penetrate.

2. Use the strips as directed on the box.  The instructions will tell you to bleach twice a day for 30-minutes a time.  The inner part of the strip has a chemical called hydrogen peroxide; (in-office, or dentist-assisted dental whitening uses a 15-35% version of the same chemical) that causes the stains inside your teeth to be oxidized and turn white. Applying the strips has a small learning curve as you will probably bend or fold a couple of them before you get the technique down.

2. Leave the strips on for the time recommended in the instructions and do not overbleach your teeth, as this leads to sensitivity.

Disadvantages

1. Hydrogen Peroxide can "burn" your gums. If you notice a burning sensation when you use the product, it is the chemical oxidizing (or burning) your gums (it will turn them white with a minor chemical burn). Depending on how severe the burning is, it may cause you to want to stop the treatment. It is OK to stop the treatment for a day or two to let the gums heal. Once they are healed, resume treatment with the White Strips. Try to not get the strip on your gums.

2. Your teeth may become senstiive during the week treatment time. Try to tolerate the sensitivity if it is mild, but if more severe, take a day or two off to let the teeth settle down and then pick up where you left off. You may notice much more sensitivity to cold water, ice cream, etc.  The peroxide causes an inflamation of the inner pulp, or nerve center of the tooth and makes the teeth very sensitive to biting or cold drinks or foods.  If your teeth become too sensitive, back off on the strips until the sensitivity is gone before resuming bleaching.

3. The strips only cover your front teeth, so only your front teeth will bleach. You may notice the distinct difference between the back (unbleached) teeth and the front (bleached) teeth. Since most people notice the front 6 teeth anyway, this is not a big deal. However, if you have a wide toothy smile, you may want to have a dentist make you a tray that will hold the chemical on the back teeth to whiten them too.

4. The bleaching effect works best on yellow stains. If your stains are due to tetracycline (brownish grey stains in a band on your teeth, your best bet is to have a dentist whiten your teeth as the dentist will use a tray to hold a more concentrated form of the chemical on your teeth for a longer period of time.

Now comes the confusing part: Crest White Strips come in 4 different packages, each a bit different than the others.  The main difference is in the strength of the hydrogen peroxide, and the price.  The higher the dose of hydrogen peroxide, the most costly the product package.  Here are the 4 packages:  1. Crest White Strips Classic (6% hydrogen peroxide, 14-day treatment).  2. Crest White Strips Premium (10% hydrogen peroxide, 7-day treatment).  3. Crest White Strips Premium Plus (10% hydrogen peroxide, and has 12 additional strips).  4. I am a dentist who recommends Crest-brand White Strips to my patients becasue they do work to whiten teeth. However, they have to be used correctly and I recommend that you follow the directions exactly as specified inside the box.

1. First brush your teeth with a wet toothbrush to remove the layer of plaque (toothpaste is unnecessary). Rinse your teeth well with water.  Tooth enamel has pores, and the pores need to be open for the chemical to penetrate.

2. Use the strips as directed on the box.  The instructions will tell you to bleach twice a day for 30-minutes a time.  The inner part of the strip has a chemical called hydrogen peroxide; (in-office, or dentist-assisted dental whitening uses a 15-35% version of the same chemical) that causes the stains inside your teeth to be oxidized and turn white. Applying the strips has a small learning curve as you will probably bend or fold a couple of them before you get the technique down.

2. Leave the strips on for the time recommended in the instructions and do not overbleach your teeth, as this leads to sensitivity.

Disadvantages

1. Hydrogen Peroxide can "burn" your gums. If you notice a burning sensation when you use the product, it is the chemical oxidizing (or burning) your gums (it will turn them white with a minor chemical burn). Depending on how severe the burning is, it may cause you to want to stop the treatment. It is OK to stop the treatment for a day or two to let the gums heal. Once they are healed, resume treatment with the White Strips. Try to not get the strip on your gums.

2. Your teeth may become senstiive during the week treatment time. Try to tolerate the sensitivity if it is mild, but if more severe, take a day or two off to let the teeth settle down and then pick up where you left off. You may notice much more sensitivity to cold water, ice cream, etc.  The peroxide causes an inflamation of the inner pulp, or nerve center of the tooth and makes the teeth very sensitive to biting or cold drinks or foods.  If your teeth become too sensitive, back off on the strips until the sensitivity is gone before resuming bleaching.

3. The strips only cover your front teeth, so only your front teeth will bleach. You may notice the distinct difference between the back (unbleached) teeth and the front (bleached) teeth. Since most people notice the front 6 teeth anyway, this is not a big deal. However, if you have a wide toothy smile, you may want to have a dentist make you a tray that will hold the chemical on the back teeth to whiten them too.

4. The bleaching effect works best on yellow stains. If your stains are due to tetracycline (brownish grey stains in a band on your teeth, your best bet is to have a dentist whiten your teeth as the dentist will use a tray to hold a more concentrated form of the chemical on your teeth for a longer period of time.

Now comes the confusing part: Crest White Strips come in 4 different packages, each a bit different than the others.  The main difference is in the strength of the hydrogen peroxide, and the price.  The higher the dose of hydrogen peroxide, the most costly the product package.  Here are the 4 packages:  1. Crest White Strips Classic (6% hydrogen peroxide, 14-day treatment).  2. Crest White Strips Premium (10% hydrogen peroxide, 7-day treatment).  3. Crest White Strips Premium Plus (10% hydrogen peroxide, and has 12 additional strips).  4. Crest White Strips Renewal (9.5% hydrogen peroxide).  The cheapest method (at around 25 dollars, is the Crest Classic Whitestrips, but it takes 2 weeks to complete the treatment).  Premium and Premium Pro are both 10% peroxide formulations, work in 7-10 days, and the "Premuim-Plus" gives you 12 additional strips.  I am not sure why Crest recently came out with "Renewal", as it is a 9.5% hydrogen peroxide formulation which is not significantly different from the 10% concentration. Leave it to the manufacturer to confuse the consumer!

Crest White Strips work for the vast majority of people. Younger people with yellow stains seem to respond better than older people or those with gray stains.  White Strips don't work as fast as a dentist-made custom tray bleaching, (or in-office bleaching) but over time, you will get a result that will be close to that of a dentist, and you will save money too.

I recommend starting with with either the Classic or the Premium-Pro. The Classic works in 2 weeks and is about $1.80 a day.  The Premium Pro works in 10 days and is about $2 dollars a day.  The Premium and Premium Pro are likely to give you more sensitivity than the Classic.  Be sure and check out the price of each kit, as they vary from store to store.  Obviously, get the cheapest kit that supplies the same amount of strips.

If you are not satisfied with the results and still want whiter teeth, you can then see your dentist for a more concentrated form of bleaching using a custom-tray system or in-office bleaching. First off, I expected it to be smaller than it is. The last one of the face cleaners I received from another company was half this size, and the advertised price was even more. Packaged with this Fyola cleaner comes one brush already attached, with a cover on the brush to protect the bristles. Also included is a second brush head, with slightly firmer bristles, and also has a cover on it. There's also a charging cable and a charging stand.

I was pleasantly surprised to find it was a wireless charging device. You just set the Fyola in the stand and it starts charging. Note that it needs to be in the charging stand facing away from you, not towards you like you might expect. You'll know you have it in the right way because the face cleaner will beep at you and the lights for each of the various setting will light up showing it's charging.

When the battery runs low, the Fyola beeps at you to let you know it's needing recharged. There are 4 different cleaning settings, sensitive, pulse life massage, exfoliate and deep clean. And they aren't kidding when they call the 4th setting deep clean. It's a strong setting that works great for getting color-stay foundation makeup out of pours.

There is an included instruction manual but it's so easy to use you really don't need to reference it for much, other than maybe familiarizing yourself with which setting is which.  The Fyola works surprisingly well and is a great full sized face cleaner.
